title: 110_s3383
content: The Act may be cited as the "Harriet Tubman National Historical Park and Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park Act". Harriet Tubman, born into slavery in Maryland around 1822, emancipated herself in 1849. She returned repeatedly to Dorchester and Caroline Counties to lead family members to freedom in the northern US and Canada. Harriet Tubman, known as "Moses" by African-Americans and abolitionists, was a prominent conductor of the Underground Railroad. Frederick Douglass praised her for her bravery in serving enslaved people. During the Civil War, Tubman worked as a nurse, scout, and spy for Union troops, helping rescue hundreds of enslaved individuals in Virginia, Florida, and South Carolina. Harriet Tubman established a home for aged African-Americans in Auburn, New York, which she later bequeathed to the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church. There are significant resources related to Tubman in Maryland and New York, including her residence, the Tubman Home for the Aged, the Thompson Memorial AME Zion Church, and her final resting place in Fort Hill Cemetery. The National Park Service should increase scholarship on the African-American experience pre-Civil War. It is important to preserve resources related to Harriet Tubman for future generations. The Act aims to preserve and promote resources in Auburn, New York, and Maryland linked to Tubman's life and contributions. The Act aims to preserve and promote resources in Caroline, Dorchester, and Talbot Counties, Maryland, related to the life and contributions of Harriet Tubman. It also establishes partnerships for resource protection, research, education, and grants for scholars of African-American history. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "Church" referring to the Thompson Memorial AME Zion Church in Auburn, New York, "Historically black college or university" as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965, "Predominantly black institution" as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965, "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, and "Visitor center" as the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad State Park Visitor Center to be constructed. Establishment of Harriet Tubman National Historical Park. The Secretary shall establish the Harriet Tubman National Historical Park in Auburn, New York, and publish notice of its establishment in the Federal Register. The park shall include structures and properties associated with Harriet Tubman's home, the Tubman Home for the Aged, the Church, and the Rectory, as depicted on a specific map available for public inspection. The Secretary may acquire land within the Historical Park boundary from willing sellers through donation, purchase, or exchange. Financial assistance may be provided for historic preservation, rehabilitation, research, maintenance, and interpretation of the Historical Park properties. Grants and cooperative agreements can be made with the Church, Fort Hill Cemetery Association for Harriet Tubman's gravesite, and the State of New York. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for preservation, research, and interpretation of Harriet Tubman resources in Auburn, New York. Interpretive tours to sites outside the Historical Park boundaries are allowed. A General Management Plan must be developed within 3 years. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Church, must complete a general management plan for the Historical Park within 3 years. Coordination with other related parks and networks is required. Establishment of the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park. The Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park is established in Maryland, consisting of landscapes and resources related to Harriet Tubman and the Underground Railroad. The boundary may be modified to include additional sites. The Secretary may acquire land within the Historical Park boundaries through various means and provide grants as per section 7(b)(2). Additionally, upon boundary modification, a revised map of the Historical Park will be made available for public inspection. The Secretary may provide grants for land acquisition in Caroline, Dorchester, and Talbot Counties, Maryland, within the Historical Park boundary. Grants may also be given for the construction of the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad State Park Visitor Center in Dorchester County, Maryland, subject to certain conditions. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for the restoration, research, stewardship programs, education, signage, and construction of the Visitor Center at the Harriet Tubman Historical Park in Maryland. Grants and cooperative agreements can be given to various entities for these purposes. The Secretary may provide interpretive tours outside the Historical Park in Maryland related to Harriet Tubman and the Underground Railroad. A general management plan must be completed within 3 years in coordination with Maryland, political subdivisions, and the US Fish and Wildlife Service. The general management plan for the Historical Park prioritizes the protection, interpretation, and research of key sites like Stewart's Canal, the Jacob Jackson home site, the Brodess Farm, and the Ben Ross and Anthony Thompson properties in Maryland. The Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge includes privately owned properties like the Ross and Anthony Thompson properties and the James Cook site. An interagency agreement promotes stewardship of Harriet Tubman resources at the refuge. The Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge is managed by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, and this Act does not change their authorities in managing the refuge. The Secretary administers the Harriet Tubman National Historical Park and the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park in accordance with applicable laws. Park regulations apply only to Federal land within the boundary of the Underground Railroad National Historical Park. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorized appropriations for the Harriet Tubman National Historical Park and the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park include funds for National Park Service personnel and management. Grants are also authorized for historic preservation, rehabilitation, restoration, and exhibit development within the parks. Authorized appropriations for the Harriet Tubman National Historical Park and the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park include funds for National Park Service personnel and management, as well as grants for historic preservation, rehabilitation, restoration, and exhibit development. Additionally, funding is allocated for grants to the State of Maryland for various activities, competitive grants to historically Black colleges and universities for research on Harriet Tubman and the African-American experience. The Federal share of the cost for activities provided assistance under subsection (b)(3) shall not exceed 75 percent, and the non-Federal share may be in the form of in-kind contributions.
